articles.headline: Murdoch’s Journal: Don’t Expect ‘Hedgeless Funds’ Headlines
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch is buying another paper because he is a sentimentalist, not because he has great skill at making money with them.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch is buying another paper because he is a sentimentalist, not because he has great skill at making money with them.
articles.lead_paragraph: You can bet serious money — billions even — that the article about the sale of The Wall Street Journal and the rest of Dow Jones & Company in today’s Journal will be fully and ferociously reported, with no quarter given to its new owner, Rupert Murdoch.

articles.headline: Keep Your Eyes on Adjustable-Rate Mortgages
articles.snippet: The pool of people falling behind on their house payments is starting to widen, and adjustable-rate mortgages are the main reason.
articles.abstract: The pool of people falling behind on their house payments is starting to widen, and adjustable-rate mortgages are the main reason.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, when the housing market was roaring along, I called a mortgage broker on the West Coast and asked for some help. I told him that I wanted to interview some recent home buyers who had taken out an adjustable-rate mortgage — one of the big drivers of the boom — and he was nice enough to pass along a short list of names.

articles.headline: Dow Jones Deal Gives Murdoch a Coveted Prize
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch has enough support from the Bancroft family for his News Corporation to buy the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch has enough support from the Bancroft family for his News Corporation to buy the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize yesterday, gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal and one of the world’s most respected news sources, for $5 billion.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Jittery Stock Market Drops as Mortgage Fallout Spreads
articles.snippet: With little respite on the horizon, the mortgage market was hit with another wave of bad news Tuesday.
articles.abstract: With little respite on the horizon, the mortgage market was hit with another wave of bad news Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: With little respite on the horizon, the mortgage market was hit with another wave of bad news yesterday, sending the stock market down sharply.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Amid War, Passion for TV Chefs, Soaps and Idols
articles.snippet: Television, which was illegal under the Taliban, is off to a phenomenal start in a developing Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Television, which was illegal under the Taliban, is off to a phenomenal start in a developing Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 25 — Seven years ago, during a very different time in a very different Afghanistan, a medical student named Daoud Sediqi was bicycling from campus when he was stopped by the Taliban’s whip-wielding religious police. The young man immediately felt an avalanche of regret, for he was in violation of at least two laws.

articles.headline: In Murdoch’s Past, Clues to The Journal’s Future
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch is likely to accept losses on The Wall Street Journal at first in order to win the long-term war.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch is likely to accept losses on The Wall Street Journal at first in order to win the long-term war.
